0: MICHAEL Chamberlain has hailed the reopening of an inquest into the death of his daughter Azaria at Uluru in 1980. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “I'm really just pleasantly surprised about this and I'm incredibly gratified,” Mr Chamberlain told ABC radio. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “It's been 31 years now and I just hope, well I'm sure this time it will be the ultimate verdict which we've been looking for, for this length of time.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The new inquest is expected to begin in February. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Northern Territory Coroner Elizabeth Morris has cited new information for reopening the inquest into the death of Azaria, who was nine weeks old when she disappeared from her parents' tent at Uluru. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Ms Morris is reopening the inquiry mainly because of information provided by the Chamberlains' legal counsel regarding dingo attacks since Azaria's disappearance, Fairfax reports. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Lindy Chamberlain was convicted of murdering Azaria and sentenced to life imprisonment in 1982, while her then-husband Michael was given a suspended sentence after being found guilty of being an accessory after the fact. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A subsequent royal commission exonerated the Chamberlains in 1987. Their convictions were quashed but a further coroner's inquest in 1995 delivered
